discussion.content: I think the answer is correct. Composite entities can be exposed as XML documents with embedded element tags for enclosed (composed) entities (e.g., for header and for lines). XML is the only way to expose a composite entity in data management.
I would say - entity only, both, composite and both.

Seem like the second should be both: 

A data entity is a conceptual abstraction and encapsulation of one or more underlying tables. It represents a common data concept or functionality, such as Customers or Vendors. Data entities are intended to be easily understood by users familiar with business concepts.

A composite data entity (can only be batched/asynchronous) allows you to build a single entity by leveraging multiple entities that are related to each other. The concept is heavily used in scenarios where an entity can be represented as a single document, like Sales header/line, Invoice header/line and Vendor Catalog.

Composite data entities are only supported in Asynchronous batched integrations. If part 2 is not both, I'd be interested to know how composite data entities are used.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/develop-composite-data-entities#what-is-a-composite-entity
Normally batched integration would be implemented for something like a sales or purchase order or some document which has header and lines. I think the answer for second option is "both"
Incorrect answer, Implement batched data integration is "both" not "OData only"

discussion.content: Configuration and data manager (preview): lets you copy a configuration from one instance to another. You can copy from and to environments that meet the following criteria: they are managed as part of an LCS project; they run the Data Import/Export Framework.
USE DATA IMPORT/EXPORT WORKSPACE

You are a functional consultant who is deploying Dynamics 365 Finance.
The implementation must:
✑ Use an iterative approach
✑ Integrate with real-world data
✑ Implement multiple rounds of feedback
You need to deploy and validate the implementation.
Solution: Perform a fit-gap analysis. Configure Dynamics 365 Finance to address the functional gap. Deploy the configuration.
Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The solution does not meet the goal, because it does not use an iterative approach. Performing a fit-gap analysis, configuring Dynamics 365 Finance, and deploying the configuration are steps that are part of a traditional waterfall approach
https://kurthatlevik.com/2017/09/14/a-practical-guide-for-dynamics-365-iterative-implementation/
Correct

a,B,E is correct answer

comments.content: @Jobart can you please share any related document link for it.

discussion.content:
here are the stages of a production test flow:

The item master is designed and released to a legal entity.
- Item requirements are created.
- Production orders are generated.
- Purchase orders are generated.
- Production order processing occurs (shop floor).
- Vendor payment (payment of purchase orders) occurs, and so on.
So according to that description, answer should be A,D,E 
B=Items requirements are present, does not mean created.
A B E are correct
A, B, E ---- ANSWER

According to this docs, everything is correct... someone can explain?

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/migration-upgrade/upgrade-functional-validation
A,B,D is correct, we are testing "production flow" so we need to make sure production orders can be created

comments.content: I think this “Production” is production environment, not production process.

discussion.content: A,B,E. Only Finance module, not Operations

choices.E: The item master is designed and released to a legal entity
